item.title: Find Cooridinates on mouse click
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

No, the point you are missing, ephemeral, is that there is no component in Java to send events when the mouse is clicked outside of the frame. Therefore, there is no component to listen for the events either. The method you provided checks the current mouse coordinate. You also could not create a class for dispatching/listening for these type of events unless you built a class to loop and check for changes in the mouse coordinates. This would be costly on the cpu usage and is probably a bad idea.

nueb35:

hmm, i thought when mouse was clicked out side of the frame, it would show “cliked -1, -1” like in mouse motion listeners, thay show when mose moves out side of frame as -1,-1 right?

Nope, they don’t. The MouseEvent class is only dispatched when the mouse effects the Window itself.

item.title: Find Cooridinates on mouse click
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

But why do you have to detece the click? There might be something I don’t get here.

If you click on a certain place, your mouse cursor would already be located on that place, and then it would just to be for him to retrieve the coordinates either before the click or after it…

For instance:

[code]import static java.awt.event.InputEvent.BUTTON1_MASK;

private int currentX;
private int currentY;

public static final void press(int x, int y) {
if(ROBOT != null) {
robot.mouseMove(x, y);
robot.mousePress(BUTTON1_MASK);
robot.mouseRelease(BUTTON1_MASK);
currentX = getX();//Or instead of getX(), you could use x.
currentY = getY();//Or instead of getY(), you could use y.
}
else {
System.out.println(“Error: You need to instantiate the Robot first.”);
}
}

public static final int getX() {
PointerInfo pointerInfo = MouseInfo.getPointerInfo();
return new Double(pointerInfo.getLocation().getX()).intValue();
}

public static final int getY() {
PointerInfo pointerInfo = MouseInfo.getPointerInfo();
return new Double(pointerInfo.getLocation().getY()).intValue();
}[/code]

item.title: Find Cooridinates on mouse click
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

If you are clicking inside of a JFrame, you can use the MouseListener interface to track the coordinates of the mouse inside the JFrame itself. You can add the location of the JFrame on the screen to those coordinates to get the mouse coordinates on the screen itself.

If you are moving the mouse and clicking outside of the Window, then you would have to already know the coordinates because you need to use Robot for that.

However, it appears that you are trying to track the mouse coordinates when the JFrame is not doing the moving/clicking. You could always try making a full screen Window that was not being painted and then just receive Mouse Events. I am sure it is possible to do that, but I do not know if it would work.

item.title: Find Cooridinates on mouse click
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

You can get the mouse coordinates from outside your application. Here are some examples:

[code]public static final int getX() {
PointerInfo pointerInfo = MouseInfo.getPointerInfo();
return new Double(pointerInfo.getLocation().getX()).intValue();
}

public static final int getY() {
PointerInfo pointerInfo = MouseInfo.getPointerInfo();
return new Double(pointerInfo.getLocation().getY()).intValue();
}

public static final Point getPoint() {
PointerInfo pointerInfo = MouseInfo.getPointerInfo();
return pointerInfo.getLocation();
}[/code]

You need to import the following:

import java.awt.MouseInfo; import java.awt.Point; import java.awt.PointerInfo;
